p: Morbidity, as well as mortality, varied from one to another outbreak. For example, in South Africa in 1975 [ 44] and in Tanzania in 2007 [ 19] most of RVF severe cases presented with encephalopathy (respectively 71% and 89%), whereas hemorrhagic manifestations predominated in Mauritania in 2015 (81%) [ 45] and Madagascar in 2008 (88%) [ 46]. In Saudi Arabia in 2000, hepatic insufficiency (75%) and renal failures (41%) were the most frequent complications [ 47]. Moreover, during the epidemic in Madagascar, highly fatal associations of two or more complications were highlighted. These occurred in 11/16 (69%) severe cases, of whom 5 (45%) had encephalitis with hemorrhagic symptoms which were lethal in 2/5 (40%), representing half of the deaths (4/16) [ 46]. Variations in the RVFV tropism and virulence are hypothesized according to the lineage involved and the possible accumulation of genetic mutations or genomic reassortments [ 17, 48– 50], despite a low overall genomic diversity (∼ 5%) at the nucleotide level [ 51]. Genetic, ethnic or epidemiologic factors in the population exposed to the virus, as well as access to care also play a role [ 17, 52].
